description: Either from unify +‎ -ification or from French unification

entries.meaning: (mathematical logic, computer science) Given two terms, their join with respect to a specialisation order.
examples: 5.7.T ( Unification theorem ) For any two terms or formulas without quantifiers X and Y, the following holds.(i) The unification algorithm UNIF1, applied to X, Y, terminates after a finite number of steps.(ii) {X, Y} is unifiable iff UNIF1 so indicates upon ter- mination. Moreover, the substitution σ then available as out- put is a most general unifier of {X, Y}.
